adverb &amp; preposition.description: Moving in one side and out of the other side of (an opening, channel, or location)
examples: as soon as we opened the gate they came streaming through
synonyms: from one side of … to the other

adverb &amp; preposition.description: Continuing in time toward completion of (a process or period)
examples: he showed up halfway through the second act

adverb &amp; preposition.description: So as to inspect all or part of (a collection, inventory, or publication)
examples: flipping through the pages of a notebook
she read the letter through carefully

adverb &amp; preposition.description: Up to and including (a particular point in an ordered sequence)
examples: they will be in town from March 24 through May 7

adverb &amp; preposition.description: By means of (a process or intermediate stage)
examples: dioxins get into mothers' milk through contaminated food

adverb &amp; preposition.description: So as to be connected by telephone.
examples: he put a call through to the senator

adjective.description: (of a means of public transportation or a ticket) continuing or valid to the final destination.
(of a room) running the whole length of a building.
Having no prospect of any future relationship, dealings, or success.
examples: she told him she was through with him

phrases: Harriet was a political animal through and through
I am a republican through and through - and given half the chance I would abolish our monarchy tomorrow.
Considered one of the last performers to come out of the string band tradition, Armstrong is a bluesman through and through.
Then the demise of Social Security becomes a Republican deed through and through.
However, I don't think anyone can defend the script or acting - it is terrible through and through.
origin: Old English thurh (preposition and adverb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch door and German durch. The spelling change to thr- appears c 1300, becoming standard from Caxton onwards.
